com.link_intersystems.events

Class EventMethod<L,E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.link_intersystems.events.EventMethod<L,E>
  • Type Parameters:
    L - the event listener type.
    E - the event object type.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Predicate<Method>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ActionEventMethod, AdjustmentEventMethod, AncestorEventMethod, BeanContextMembershipEventMethod, BeanContextServiceRevokedEventMethod, CaretEventMethod, CellEditorEventMethod, ChangeEventMethod, ComponentEventMethod, ConnectionEventMethod, ContainerEventMethod, DocumentEventMethod, FocusEventMethod, HierarchyBoundsEventMethod, HierarchyEventMethod, InternalFrameEventMethod, ItemEventMethod, KeyEventMethod, ListDataEventMethod, ListSelectionEventMethod, MenuEventMethod, MouseEventMethod, MouseWheelEventMethod, NamespaceChangeEventMethod, NamingEventMethod, NodeChangeEventMethod, PopupMenuEventMethod, PropertyChangeMethod, RowSetEventMethod, StatementEventMethod, TableColumnModelEventMethod, TableModelEventMethod, TreeExpansionEventMethod, TreeModelEventMethod, TreeSelectionEventMethod, VetoableChangeMethod, WindowEventMethod, WindowFocusEventMethod, WindowStateEventMethod

    public class EventMethod<L,E>
extends Object
implements Predicate<Method>
    An EventMethod is an adapter that can adapt method references, such as Runnable, Consumer and BiConsumer, to event listener methods. 
     public class EventMethodUsageExample {

     public static void main(String[] args) {
         EventMethodUsageExample eventMethodUsageExample = new EventMethodUsageExample();
         eventMethodUsageExample.setSelection(3);
         eventMethodUsageExample.setSelection(5);
     }

     private ListSelectionListener l1 = ListSelectionEventMethod.VALUE_CHANGED.listener(this::printEventFired);

     private ListSelectionListener l2 = ListSelectionEventMethod.VALUE_CHANGED.listener(
             this::printSelectionChanged,
             ListSelectionEvent::getLastIndex,
             ">>> ", e -> !e.getValueIsAdjusting());

     private ListSelectionModel selectionModel = new DefaultListSelectionModel();

     EventMethodUsageExample() {
         selectionModel.setSelectionMode(ListSelectionModel.SINGLE_SELECTION);
         selectionModel.addListSelectionListener(l1);
         selectionModel.addListSelectionListener(l2);
     }

     public void setSelection(int index) {
         selectionModel.setValueIsAdjusting(true);
         selectionModel.setSelectionInterval(index, index);
         selectionModel.setValueIsAdjusting(false);
     }

     private void printEventFired(ListSelectionEvent e) {
         int firstIndex = e.getFirstIndex();
         int lastIndex = e.getLastIndex();
         boolean isAdjusting = e.getValueIsAdjusting();
         System.out.println("Selection model event fired:" +
                 " firstIndex= " + firstIndex +
                 " lastIndex= " + lastIndex +
                 " isAdjusting= " + isAdjusting);
     }

     private void printSelectionChanged(int selectedIndex, String indent) {
         System.out.println(indent + "Index " + selectedIndex + " selected");
     }
 }

    Running the example code above will output: 

     Selection model event fired: firstIndex= 3 lastIndex= 3 isAdjusting= true
 >>> Index 3 selected
 Selection model event fired: firstIndex= 3 lastIndex= 3 isAdjusting= false
 Selection model event fired: firstIndex= 3 lastIndex= 5 isAdjusting= true
 >>> Index 5 selected
 Selection model event fired: firstIndex= 3 lastIndex= 5 isAdjusting= false

    • Constructor Detail

      • EventMethod

        protected EventMethod(String... methodNames)
        Creates an EventMethod which supports the given event methods (by name) and whose event listener class and event object class are resolved by the generic type arguments that a subclass defines . E.g. 
         public class ActionEventMethod extends EventMethod<ActionListener, ActionEvent> {

     public static final ActionEventMethod PERFORMED = new ActionEventMethod("actionPerformed");

     public ActionEventMethod(String... methodNames) {
         super(methodNames);
     }
 }

        The resolution algorithm also searches superclasses. E.g. 

             abstract class BaseEventMethod extends EventMethod<SomeListener, SomeEvent> {
     }

     class ExtendsBase extends BaseEventMethod {
     }

        But the search algorithm has limitations. E.g. you can not split the type definition in the hierarchy. E.g. 

             abstract class BaseEventMethod extends EventMethod {
     }

     class ExtendsBase extends BaseEventMethod<SomeListener> {
     }

        and you may also not swap the type parameter positions. 

             abstract class BaseEventMethod<E extends EventObject, L> extends EventMethod {
     }

     class ExtendsBase extends BaseEventMethod<SomeEvent, SomeListener> {
     }

        However, you can pass the arguments through multiple hierarchy levels. 

             abstract class BaseEventMethod<L, E extends EventObject> extends EventMethod<L, E> {
     }

     class ExtendsBase extends BaseEventMethod<SomeListener, SomeEvent> {
     }

        or you can simply create an anonymous class if you don't want to create a custom subclass. 

             EventMethod eventMethod = new EventMethod<SomeListener, SomeEvent>(){};
        Parameters:
        methodNames - the method names that this EventMethod should support.

      • EventMethod

        public EventMethod(Class<L> listenerClass,
                   Class<E> eventObjectClass,
                   String... methodNames)
        Creates an EventMethod based on the given listener and event object type that supports the defined methodNames.

    • Method Detail

      • isCompatible

        public boolean isCompatible(EventMethod<?,?> otherEventMethod)
        Returns true if this EventMethod is compatible to the otherEventMethod. This EventMethod is compatible to the otherEventMethod if the event listener class and the event object class are equal.
        Parameters:
        otherEventMethod - the EventMethod to check compatibility with.
        Returns:
        true if this EventMethod's event listener class and event object class is compatible to the otherEventMethod.

      • join

        public EventMethod<L,E> join(EventMethod<L,E> otherEventMethod)
        A joined EventMethod is an EventMethod that supports this EventMethod's methods and the EventMethod methods of the other EventMethod.

        Assume you have defined an EventMethod that supports the mouse clicked event. 

           EventMethod<hMouseListener,MouseEvent> clickedEvent = new EventMethod<>(MouseListener.class, MouseEvent.class, "mouseClicked");

        and an EventMethod that supports the mouse pressed event. 

           EventMethod<hMouseListener,MouseEvent> pressedEvent = new EventMethod<>(MouseListener.class, MouseEvent.class, "mousePressed");

        You can then create a new EventMethod that supports both event methods by joining them. 

           EventMethod<hMouseListener,MouseEvent> clickedAndPressedEvents = clickedEvent.join(pressedEvent);

        Parameters:
        otherEventMethod - the other event method to join with.
        Returns:
        a new EventMethod instance that supports all event methods of this and the otherEventMethod.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the otherEventMethod is incompatible with this event and can therefore not be joined. The otherEventMethod is incompatible if the event listener class or the event object class are not equal.
        See Also:
        isCompatible(EventMethod)
